author: Nigrone, Giovanni Antonio
summary: In the 2nd vol. of his handwritten book titled Varii Discorsi', the fountaineer G.A. Nigrone mentions a series of disasters that struck Naples and Southern Italy in the previous centuries, including the eruption of Monte Nuovo in 1538. He states that he derived the information on this event from his father's accounts, yet his description is very similar to that published in 1539 by M.A Delli Falconi. The author challenges the idea that such events are a prelude to other disasters, but may be followed by disasters 'naturally' connected to them, such as drought and famine'

The people who managed to save themselves did so thanks to their prayers addressed to the Virgin, the saints and the angels. According to Poma de Ayala, Arequipa was devastated by fire, but in one of the images of that city and Arica that his work includes (volume 2, pp. 397 and 399) , he also refers to the ash that for days prevented seeing the sky in both cities.

author: Vázquez de Espinosa, Antonio
summary: The author, on p. 469, states that the ash from the eruption spread over 200 leagues and reached the ships that were sailing. Vázquez de Espinosa claims that at the time of writing there was still a lot of ash for more than 150 leagues, which he himself had seen. According to witnesses, many incandescent pumice stones fell into the Tambo river and ended up devastating farms and their livestock. When the river flowed into the sea, it ended up cooking the fish and, according to the author, it was thanks to God that their corpses did not cause a plague. The ash rain lasted seven days, prevented the sun from being seen and caused many houses to fall and burn down. The earth was scorched by the ash, which prevented it from producing fruit for a long time, as it does today.Vázquez de Espinosa's account includes the report of the soldier Pedro de Vivar (pp. 470-474) who relates the evolution of the effects of the eruption on Arequipa. According to Pedro de Vivar, in the first days, the population did not know that the rain of ash that plunged the city into darkness had been caused by the eruption of the volcano. Although some already suspected that it might have been caused by the neighbouring volcano, at first, the population considered other possibilities: that it had been caused by the sea or that it was the end of the world. Vivar's account goes into detail on the processions that took place, in which various images were exhibited, such as those of Christ, Santa Marta (advocate for the earthquakes in Arequipa), San Jacinto, San Francisco, Nuestra Señora de Copacabana, del Rosario, de Gracia and de la Consolación, as well as various relics. The soldier details the reaction of the Indians: some offered human sacrifices to the volcano, which Vivar identifies as the devil, and others decided to hang themselves, convinced by the devil. Likewise, the author of the account also points out the prominence of the religious orders in the organised religious rituals, specifically the Society of Jesus, the Dominicans (such as the prior Domingo Peres) and the Augustinians (the prior Diego Gutierres stands out). He recalls the effects on the Tambo river, transformed into a river of fire that cooked the fish once it flowed into the sea.
archive: Rome, Biblioteca Apostolica Vaticana, Barb. Lat. 3584

author: Ocaña, Diego de
summary: The manuscript has been entitled a posteriori 'Relación del viaje de fray Diego de Ocaña por el Nuevo Mundo (1599-1605)'.In the report, the friar states that although he did not witness the disaster, he heard the noise it generated even though he was many leagues away from the city of Arequipa. He describes day by day the rain of ash and fire caused by the eruption of the volcano, as well as the behaviour of the population, who initially did not know that the Huaynaputina volcano was the cause of these phenomena. He focuses on the processions of images (of Our Lady of Consolación, Santa Marta and the Blessed Sacrament), the destruction of crops, water sources and the indigenous villages near the volcano (Ornate and Puquiña). It was only thanks to the arrival of a Spaniard from the village of Ornate that the population of Arequipa learned that the cause of the phenomenology was the eruption of the volcano.  Diego de Ocaña claims to have written the report in the convent of San Francisco de Arequipa thanks to the testimonies of several witnesses of the event.
archive: Oviedo, Biblioteca Universitaria, M-215
writtenAt: [ca. 1605] It was finished around that time. The friar's journey took place between 1599 and 1605.

author: Vázquez de Espinosa, Antonio

On p. 475, Vázquez de Espinosa refers natural causes for the disaster: the volcan's presence in Nicaragua explained the earthquake.

author: Philip IV
summary: The King refers the reception of the letter of 20 August 1662 sent by the Royal Audiencia of Quito. In it, the king was informed of the rogations that had been held to placate the divine wrath caused by an earthquake on 1 January of the same year. In the ceremonies, everyone had acknowledged the Virgin as intercessor. The earthquake had ruined temples and houses and caused the loss of cattle and the sterility of the land. The king recommended that the rogations be continued, that public sins be avoided, and that justice be administered equally and righteously. The letter of 1662 took up the contents of the letter sent by the Royal Audiencia on 4 November 1660, in which they reported the eruption of a volcano located three leagues from Quito, most probably Pichincha.
archive: Seville, Archivo General de Indias, Quito, 210, L. 4, ff. 17r-17v

author: Liñán y Cisneros, Melchor de
summary: Liñán informed the king of the earthquake of 1678 and the measures adopted to appease the divine wrath. The earthquake mainly affected the temples, especially the cathedral. The viceroy claims that the earthquake is God's way of punishing the wicked, of making amends to the contumacious or of exercising the just. But he claimed that the motives behind the earthquake couldn't be known because the divine will is inscrutable. He said that four people died in Lima and thirteen in the port of El Callao, where the sea was very restless. He reported too how, after the earthquake, he went out with Conde de Castelar, then viceroy, to survey the damage.
archive: Seville, Archivo General de Indias, Lima, 78

author: Liñán y Cisneros, Melchor de
summary: The archbishop claims that the earthquake caused sacred and profane buildings to shake and made Lima look like a Ninivie in the face of the preaching of the prophet Jonah. The reconstruction cost many thousands of ducats. Melchor de Liñán also recounted how he was asked to take over as viceroy eighteen days after the earthquake. He considered this assignment providential because if the secular power of the king and the ecclesiastical power were in the hands of one person, it was thus possible to repair both buildings and men.
archive: Archivio Apostolico Vaticano, Congregazione del Concilio, Relationes, vol. 450

author: Caccia, Federico
summary: News arrived from Cadiz about the arrival of three ships of the fleet with the Capitana so damaged by the storms that, according to the nuncio, it is a miracle that it made it to safety. The ship's voyage logs attested to the storms it suffered, which resulted in one ship being lost and two others being abandoned after their cargo was picked up and people disembarked. Because of the many hardships suffered by the fleet, the Council of the Indies resolved on Sunday to celebrate the feast of Our Lady of the Rosary every year who in the past was invoked with profitable success in the greatest dangers.
archive: Archivio Apostolico Vaticano, Segreteria di Stato, Spagna, vol. 173, fols. 461r-462r

author: Unknown
summary: The document is the report of the 1695 Jesuit fathers' mission to Bitonto. After their mission in Bitonto, three Jesuits went to the dioceses of Bovino and Trevico to hear confessions and preach, but they faced difficulties in finding beds and accommodation in Trevico, devastated by the 1694 earthquake
archive: Archivum Romanum Societatis Iesu, Neap_76_I, ff. 306r – 309r

author: Consejo de Indias
summary: Discussion about the Quito archbishop's letter dated 19 March 1706 (letter included) in which the prelate requests permission for the definitive move of the Carmelite nuns of Latacunga to the new monastery built for them in Quito. The original monastery was distroyed in 1698 by an earthquake. It is said that in August 1700 the Council had learned of the earthquake from the letter of the Count of Monclova, viceroy of Peru. In this letter, the viceroy reported that all the churches and houses had been destroyed and so there were discussions about moving the cities of Riobamba and Ambato. The viceroy knew of this thanks to information from the president and oidores of the Royal Audiencia of Quito and from private individuals. Latacunga did not appear among the petitioners mentioned by the viceroy. For this reason, the Consejo de Indias decided to ask Latacunga for its opinion on the transfer of the Carmelite convent to Quito and also to the city of Quito, which already had a Carmelite convent.
archive: Seville, Archivo General de Indias, Quito, 182

author: Consejo de Indias
summary: Discussion of a request made by the Viceroy of Peru by letter of 1 September 1753. In this letter, the viceroy requested the establishment of a Jesuit college in Bellavista, a town founded near El Callao after it was destroyed by the earthquake and tsunami of 1746. The viceroy also requested the foundation of a hospital to be administered by the order of San Juan de Dios. The council supported the viceroy's proposals.
archive: Seville, Archivo General de Indias, Lima, 520

summary: Report of the Governor of Terra d'Otranto based on engineer Felice de Riso's assessment of the damage suffered by the walls of Barletta following last year's disasters. Since the income of the Università was less than the expenses, mere tax exemption would not have allowed for the repair of the walls. The strategic importance of the square in countering corsair raids prompted the governor to advise the Sommaria to take appropriate measures.
archive: Naples, Archivio di Stato di Napoli, Regia Camera della Sommaria, Segreteria, Consultationum, vol. 48, ff. 184r-v

archive: Vatican City, Archivio Apostolico Vaticano, Segreteria di Stato, Napoli, vol. 61 D

author: Spinola, Giulio (Apostolic Nuncio)

archive: Vatican City, Archivio Apostolico Vaticano, Segreteria di Stato, Napoli, vol. 61 D

author: Spinola, Giulio (Apostolic Nuncio)
summary: First notice of the Apostolic Nuncio on the damage caused by the Earthquake of 5 November 1659.
archive: Vatican City, Archivio Apostolico Vaticano, Segreteria di Stato, Napoli, vol. 61 D

author: Spinola, Giulio (Apostolic Nuncio)
summary: Pending more detailed reports on human and material losses due to the Earthquake, the Apostolic Nuncio updates the list of damaged locations.
archive: Vatican City, Archivio Apostolico Vaticano, Segreteria di Stato, Napoli, vol. 61 D

author: Spinola, Giulio (Apostolic Nuncio)
summary: The Apostolic Nuncio gives an update on the damage received in the Catanzaro area due to the Earthquake. He also reports on the Viceroy's decision to send Donato Antonio de Marinis to help those areas and to support the Duke of Girifalco. He concludes by reporting on the displaced population beginning to appear in Naples.
archive: Vatican City, Archivio Apostolico Vaticano, Segreteria di Stato, Napoli, vol. 61 D

author: Spinola, Giulio (Apostolic Nuncio)
summary: The Apostolic Nuncio informs of the mission of Donato Antonio de Marinis to report on the Earthquake damage. He also reports that the frightened population continues to remain in the countryside, despite the suffering and outbreaks of disease.
archive: Vatican City, Archivio Apostolico Vaticano, Segreteria di Stato, Napoli, vol. 61 D

author: Spinola, Giulio (Apostolic Nuncio)
summary: The Apostolic Nuncio sends the attached report on the Earthquake damage by Commissioner de Marinis.
archive: Vatican City, Archivio Apostolico Vaticano, Segreteria di Stato, Napoli, vol. 61 F

author: Spinola, Giulio (Apostolic Nuncio)
summary: The Apostolic Nuncio informs of the Viceroy's satisfaction at what he was told in person by the President of Calabria de Marinis, namely that the Earthquake damage was not as great as fame had described it.He also reports that the latest news describes that a furious wind has demolished houses already damaged by the Earthquake.
archive: Vatican City, Archivio Apostolico Vaticano, Segreteria di Stato, Napoli, vol. 61 F

author: Spinola, Giulio (Apostolic Nuncio)
summary: The Apostolic Nuncio informs that the report of the President of Calabria de Marinis describes the Earthquake damage as more extensive than fame had portrayed it.He also warns that the area continues to be shaken by Earthquakes, which even if they do not cause damage leave the population terrified.
archive: Vatican City, Archivio Apostolico Vaticano, Segreteria di Stato, Napoli, vol. 61 F

author: Visconti, Filippo (Bishop of Catanzaro)
summary: The letter from the bishop of Catanzaro gives a report on the success of the Earthquake with a description of the damage suffered by religious buildings in Catanzaro and the surrounding area. He then provides a list of the towns most affected by the Earthquake.
archive: Vatican City, Archivio Apostolico Vaticano, Segreteria di Stato, Vescovi e prelati, vol. 44, ff. 179-188

author: Visconti, Filippo (Bishop of Catanzaro)
summary: The bishop of Catanzaro provides an update on the damage in the towns most affected by the Earthquake, taken from news received from the Royal Udienza.
archive: Vatican City, Archivio Apostolico Vaticano, Segreteria di Stato, Vescovi e prelati, vol. 44

author: Visconti, Filippo (Bishop of Catanzaro)
summary: Petition of Bishop Visconti to Pope Alexander VII to grant plenary indulgence to the Earthquake-stricken diocese of Catanzaro.
archive: Rome, Archivio Generale Agostiniano, Cc 13, f. 286

author: Visconti, Filippo (Bishop of Catanzaro)
summary: Chronicle of the damage that the Earthquake caused to the convent of Santo Stefano in Catanzaro, with demonstrations of terror by the population but also of devotion and repentance. The religious orders became the leading figure in this traumatic moment that threatened the social order.
archive: Rome, Archivio Generale Agostiniano, Cc 13, ff. 264-266

author: Visconti, Filippo (Bishop of Catanzaro)
recipient: Valvassori, Girolamo (Assistant of Italy of the Augustinian Order)
summary: The bishop expresses his ongoing terror at the damage that first the Earthquake, then the fire and finally the strong wind caused to the convent of Santo Stefano in Catanzaro.
archive: Rome, Archivio Generale Agostiniano, Cc 13, ff. 296r-v

author: Visconti, Filippo (Bishop of Catanzaro)
recipient: Valvassori, Girolamo (Assistant of Italy of the Augustinian Order)
summary: The bishop of Catanzaro portrays the Earthquake as a calamity worse than plague, famine and war, because it continues to generate new fear through its tremor. Because of the danger of staying in damaged houses, the winter and the raids of brigands, he manifests his torment at not knowing where to stay or where to flee.
archive: Rome, Archivio Generale Agostiniano, Cc 13, f. 302

author: Alessandro VII (Pope)
summary: Pastoral letter to the diocese for indulgences granted by Pope Alexander VII out of compassion for the misery caused by the 1659 Earthquake.
archive: Rome, Archivio Generale Agostiniano, Cc 13, 328-333

author: Visconti, Filippo (Bishop of Catanzaro)
recipient: Bracamonte Guzmán, Gaspar de, Count of Peñaranda (Viceroy of the Kingdom of Naples)
summary: The bishop of Catanzaro describes the ruin of his cathedral caused by the Earthquake as a manifestation of divine wrath for sins committed. He therefore petitions the viceroy to recognise the cathedral under his patronage.
archive: Rome, Archivio Generale Agostiniano, Cc 13, f. 293

author: De Marinis, Antonio Donato (Special commissioner)
summary: The agent of the viceroy, Antonio Donato de Marinis, gives accounts on its mission in Calabria Ultra.
archive: Naples, Archivio di Stato di Napoli, Consiglio Collaterale, Consiglio, Notamenti, vol.64, f. 60v

author: Enríquez de Guzmán, Luis, duke of Alba (Viceroy of Peru)
summary: The viceroy acknowledges having received news of the Eruption, which began on 17 October, and encourages the city to continue processions and prayers, which on such occasions are the only remedy
archive: Quito, Archivo Municipal, Libro de Cartas escritas por los Reyes Nuestros Senores, Sumos Pontifices, Virreyes y otros Ministros de esta Real Audiencia al Cabildo de Quito, 1589-1714, f. 172

author: Audiencia of Quito
summary: Copy of a report to the sovereign made by the Audiencia of Quito, a few days after the beginning of the Eruption, describing the natural phenomena, the fear that filled the population, the demonstrations of repentance and the processions, made also recalling the Eruption that had occurred about 80 years earlier, in which the city was believed to have been protected by an image kept in the convent of Nuestra Señora de las Mercedes
archive: Quito, Archivo Historico del Banco Central del Ecuador, Fondo Jacinto Jijón y Caamaño, Primera Serie, vol. 12, fol. 2455

author: Royal Inquisition in the Canary Islands
summary: The Inquisitors of the Canary Islands sent the Supreme Inquisition a report on the Eruption, which caused 'fright' throughout the islands and much damage in La Palma. The two-page report is accompanied by a detailed drawing of the Eruption.
archive: Madrid, Archivo Histórico Nacional, Inquisición, 2376

summary: Title: Temblor de tierra. It's a transcription of two reports of the Seville Earthquake of 1504 plus one of the Andalusia Earthquake of 1680
archive: Seville, Biblioteca Capitular y Colombina, 59-1-5

author: Unknown (Procurator of the Naples College of the Society of Jesus)
recipient: Benavides, Francisco de (Viceroy of Naples, count of Santisteban)
summary: Letter from the Procurator of the Naples College of the Society of Jesus to the Viceroy concerning the request for iron to repair the College from the ruins caused by the Earthquake.
archive: Naples, Archivio di Stato di Napoli, Segreterie dei Viceré, viglietti originali, fascio 696, n. 130

author: Moles, Francesco (Regent of Cancelleria and Consiglio Collaterale)
recipient: Benavides, Francisco de (Viceroy of Naples, count of Santisteban)
summary: Letter from the Regent of the Cancelleria and the Consiglio Collaterale informing of the damage suffered by the Vicaria prison as a result of the Earthquake, where looting and other problems have occurred, possibly due to prisoners escaping. It is requested that this and other prisons in the city be inspected.
archive: Naples, Archivio di Stato di Napoli, Segreterie dei Viceré, viglietti originali, fascio 694, n. 138

author: Guglielmelli, Arcangelo (Engineer)
recipient: Unknown (Rector of the church of the convent of San Giovanni Battista delle Monache)
summary: Expert report by engineer Arcangelo Guglielmelli on the damage caused by the Earthquake and the work needed to restore the church of the convent of San Giovanni Battista delle Monache.
archive: Naples, Archivio storico diocesano di Napoli

author: Brancaccio, Carlo (Councilor of the Sacro Regio Consiglio)
recipient: Benavides, Francisco de (Viceroy of Naples, count of Santisteban)
summary: Prisons were inspected, but as far as the prison of Castel Sant'Elmo was concerned, the Earthquake had not caused the same ruin that it had caused the prisons of the Vicaria. The Beneficiata, while not considered the cause of the Earthquake, was nevertheless considered a source of social unrest. The Earthquake also caused many corpses to emerge from the ruins. Inspections are ordered on those who gamble and on the state of the courts.
archive: Naples, Archivio di Stato di Napoli, Segreterie dei Viceré, viglietti originali, fascio 694 1688, n. 180

author: Correa de Castelblanco, Rodrigo (Governor of the Torrione del Carmine in Naples)
recipient: Benavides, Francisco de (Viceroy of Naples, count of Santisteban)
summary: Letter in which the governor of the Torrione del Carmine in Naples petitions the Viceroy to repair the damage caused to the tower by the Earthquake.
archive: Naples, Archivio di Stato di Napoli, Segreterie dei Viceré, viglietti originali, fascio 694, n. 251

author: Unknown (Castellan of Capua)
recipient: Benavides, Francisco de (Viceroy of Naples, count of Santisteban)
summary: Letter from the Castellan of Capua to the Viceroy concerning the damage caused to the Capua Castle by the Earthquake.
archive: Naples, Archivio di Stato di Napoli, Segreterie dei Viceré, viglietti originali, fascio 694, n. 156

author: Unknown (Marquis of Mirabella)
recipient: Benavides, Francisco de (Viceroy of Naples, count of Santisteban)
summary: Petition in which the Marquis of Mirabella, who escaped death because he was in Naples at the time of the Earthquake, asks the Viceroy not to be harassed for debts given his state of poverty due to the Earthquake that caused damage to his estates and the death of his family.
archive: Naples, Archivio di Stato di Napoli, Segreterie dei Viceré, viglietti originali, fascio 694, n. 177

author: Unknown
recipient: Benavides, Francisco de (Viceroy of Naples, count of Santisteban)
summary: Communication to the Viceroy regarding the patrol carried out on the night of 9 June in Naples while the fear of an Earthquake for the city continues.
archive: Naples, Archivio di Stato di Napoli, Segreterie dei Viceré, viglietti originali, fascio 694, n. 185

author: Unknown
recipient: Benavides, Francisco de (Viceroy of Naples, count of Santisteban)
summary: Petition to ask the Viceroy to repair the Earthquake-damaged treasure room as soon as possible.
archive: Naples, Archivio di Stato di Napoli, Segreterie dei Viceré, viglietti originali, fascio 694, n. 252

author: Correale, Francesco
recipient: Benavides, Francisco de (Viceroy of Naples, count of Santisteban)
summary: Petition by Francesco Correale to the Viceroy for permission to return to Sorrento to repair his mother's house hit by the Earthquake.
archive: Naples, Archivio di Stato di Napoli, Segreterie dei Viceré, viglietti originali, fascio 695, n. 73

author: Gascón y Altavas, Nicolas (Secretary of Justice of Capua)
recipient: Benavides, Francisco de (Viceroy of Naples, count of Santisteban)
summary: Letter from the Secretary of Justice of Capua to the Viceroy on the effects of the Earthquake and on a matrimonial case.
archive: Naples, Archivio di Stato di Napoli, Segreterie dei Viceré, viglietti originali, fascio 695, n. 79

author: Unknown (Provost of the Casa Professa of the Society of Jesus)
recipient: Benavides, Francisco de (Viceroy of Naples, count of Santisteban)
summary: Petition from the provost of the Casa Professa of the Society of Jesus in Naples to the Viceroy concerning the request for materials to repair their Earthquake-damaged church.
archive: Naples, Archivio di Stato di Napoli, Segreterie dei Viceré, viglietti originali, fascio 695, n. 157

author: Unknown (Duchess of Jelsi)
recipient: Benavides, Francisco de (Viceroy of Naples, count of Santisteban)
summary: Petition by the Duchess of Jelsi to the Viceroy regarding a sum of money she claims as a credit to repair the damage caused to her real estate by the Earthquake.
archive: Naples, Archivio di Stato di Napoli, Segreterie dei Viceré, viglietti originali, fascio 695, n. 215

author: Panicho, Gaetano
recipient: Benavides, Francisco de (Viceroy of Naples, count of Santisteban)
summary: Petition to the Viceroy by Gaetano Panicho from Foggia, who was damaged in his income by the Earthquake and asked not to be harassed for debts.
archive: Naples, Archivio di Stato di Napoli, Segreterie dei Viceré, viglietti originali, fascio 695, n. 22

author: Natale, Antonio de
recipient: Benavides, Francisco de (Viceroy of Naples, count of Santisteban)
summary: Report by Engineer Antonio De Natale to the Viceroy on the damages suffered in the Royal Garrison of Pizzofalcone due to the Earthquake.
archive: Naples, Archivio di Stato di Napoli, Segreterie dei Viceré, viglietti originali, fascio 695, n. 266

author: Carrillo y Salcedo, Estevan (Secretary to the Viceroy)
summary: Response to the Marquis of Mirabella's petition for a deferment on the payment of debts due to his state of poverty induced by the Earthquake: the Viceroy's secretary states that in this, as in other similar cases that will arise, the course of action is not to grant deferments systematically, but on a case-by-case basis. Deferments that in any case must not exceed one year.
archive: Naples, Archivio di Stato di Napoli, Segreterie dei Viceré, viglietti originali, fascio  695, n. 34

author: Picchiatti, Francesco Antonio  (Royal Engineer)
recipient: Governors of the Greek Confraternity of SS. Pietro and Paolo
summary: Engineer Picchiatti's report on the Earthquake damage to a house owned by the Greek Monastery of SS. Pietro and Paolo.
archive: Naples, Archivio storico diocesano di Napoli, Acta Apostolica, p. 3.3

author: Picchiatti, Francesco Antonio  (Royal Engineer)
recipient: Rector of the Convent of the Monte di Dio
summary: Engineer Picchiatti's survey of the Earthquake damage to the church and convent of the Preaching Fathers of the Monte di Dio on the Pizzofalcone hill.
archive: Naples, Archivio storico diocesano di Napoli, Acta Apostolica, m-12

author: Nauclerio, Luise (Royal Engineer)
summary: Report by engineer Luise Nauclerio on behalf of the monastery of Santa Maria di Montesanto on a selection of houses owned by the monastery and damaged by the Earthquake.
archive: Naples, Archivio storico diocesano di Napoli, Acta Apostolica, m-6-16

author: Sacco, Gennaro (Tabulario)
summary: The Neapolitan 'tabulario' Gennaro Sacco estimates the damage that the Earthquake caused to the monastery of the Carmine maggiore and some houses belonging to the monastery.
archive: Naples, Archivio storico diocesano di Napoli, Acta Apostolica, c-2-6, f. 6r

author: Patremi, Antonio (Master builder)
recipient: Unknown (Rector of the Church of San Paolo Maggiore)
summary: Report of the master builder for the reconstruction of the facade of San Paolo Maggiore collapsed by the Earthquake.
archive: Naples, Archivio storico diocesano di Napoli, Acta Apostolica, p.6.10

author: Benavides, Francisco de (Viceroy of Naples, count of Santisteban)
summary: Letter from the Viceroy of Naples, Count of Santisteban, dated 11 June 1688 on the damage caused in Naples and the Kingdom by the Earthquake of 5 June 1688.
archive: Simancas, Archivo General de Simancas, Secretaría de Estado, Negociación de Nápoles, legajo 3319, f. 85

author: Consejo de Estado
summary: Advice from the Council of State concerning the letter from the Viceroy of Naples on the damage caused in Naples and the Kingdom by the Earthquake of 5 June 1688.
archive: Simancas, Archivo General de Simancas, Secretaría de Estado, Negociación de Nápoles, legajo 3319, f. 84

author: Consejo de Estado
summary: Advice from the Council of State concerning the letter from the Viceroy of Naples, Count of Santisteban, dated 11 June 1688 on the suspension of the game of the Beneficiata following the Earthquake of 5 June 1688.
archive: Simancas, Archivo General de Simancas, Secretaría de Estado, Negociación de Nápoles, legajo 3319, f. 83

author: Consejo de Estado
summary: Resolution of the Consejo de Estado, which examined the advice of the Consejo de Italia formulated on the basis of letters from Viceroy Santiesteban, the Apostolic Nuncio and the Spanish Ambassador in Rome. The resolution put an end to and prohibited the game of 'Beneficiata'.
archive: Simancas, Archivo General de Simancas, Secretaría de Estado, Negociación de Nápoles, legajo 3319, f. 86

author: Benavides, Francisco de (Viceroy of Naples, count of Santisteban)
summary: Letter from the Viceroy on the measures to cover the loss of revenue due to the suspension of the 'Beneficiata'. The revenue from the game, worth 24,000 scudi, was of great importance for the financing of the Spanish amabassy in Rome.
archive: Simancas, Archivo General de Simancas, Secretaría de Estado, Negociación de Nápoles, legajo 3319, f. 92

author: Consejo de Estado
summary: Advice of the Consejo de Estado on both the suspension of the 'Beneficiata' and the need to recover the deficit corresponding to the revenue from the game.
archive: Simancas, Archivo General de Simancas, Secretaría de Estado, Negociación de Nápoles, legajo 3319, f. 91

author: Charles II
summary: Letter of Charles II to the city council of Santander informing them about the Earthquake in Naples and asking for the celebration of a mass.
archive: Madrid, Archivo Histórico Nacional, Estado, leg. 3169, doc. 28.

author: Torre y Angulo, Manuel de la  (Quito's corregidor)
summary: The Cabildo gathers and determines to send 'experienced explorers' to verify the activity of the Pichincha and Papallacta volcanoes and of the volcanoes in the Latacunga, Ambato and Riobamba area. Later, the Cabildo learns that the tremors and rumblings being felt are the effect of the activity of the volcano known as Matas (now Sangay), whose Eruption is affecting the districts of Riobamba and Guayaquil
archive: Quito, Archivo Municipal, Actas del Cabildo de la Ciudad de San Francisco de Quito, 1689 – 1696, ff. 175-177

author: Bailía General del Real Patrimonio
summary: Lawsuit of the town of Cervià against that of Bordils, in Girona, to avoid the damage caused by the floods of the river Ter.
archive: Barcelona, Archivo de la Corona de Aragón, Bailía General del Real Patrimonio, Procesos, 1692, nº 1, Y

author: Bailía General del Real Patrimonio
summary: Lawsuit over the tree trunks that have carried the floods of the Llobregat River to the town of Cornellà de Llobregat.
archive: Barcelona, Archivo de la Corona de Aragón, Bailía General del Real Patrimonio, 1696, nº 1, D

author: Bailía General del Real Patrimonio
summary: The floods of the Llobregat River have destroyed farmland, turning it into swampy land and worthless for the Royal Patrimony.
archive: Barcelona, Archivo de la Corona de Aragón, Bailía General del Real Patrimonio, Procesos, 1696, nº 1, M

author: Bailía General del Real Patrimonio
summary: List of damages caused by the floods of the river Ter in the towns of Bordils and Cervià, in Girona.
archive: Barcelona, Archivo de la Corona de Aragón, Bailía General del Real Patrimonio, Procesos, 1699, nº 2, Ap

author: Bailía General del Real Patrimonio
summary: The village of Bordils presents possible solutions to avoid the damage caused by the great avenues of the river Ter.
archive: Barcelona, Archivo de la Corona de Aragón, Bailía General del Real Patrimonio, Procesos, 1701, nº 1, T

author: Audiencia of the Canary Islands
recipient: Rodrigo y Alós, José (Secretary of State)
summary: The map of the island contains a description of the places affected by the Eruption, titled 'Estado a que tiene reducida el volcan la ysla de Lanzarote desde el 1º dia de septiembre de 1730 asta el 29 de diciembre del mismo año', sent by the regente and Audiencia of the Canary Islands to the Secretary of State and of the Office of Justice and Political Government. It describes the damage caused to the island of Lanzarote by the volcanic Eruptions of September to December 1730
archive: Simancas, Archivo General de Simancas, Mapas, planos y dibujos, 18, 051

author: Arenaza, Pedro
summary: Relación de lo sucedido en el Perú en 28 de septiembre 1746
archive: Barcelona, Biblioteca de Catalunya, Ms. 2782

author: Díaz de la Vega, Teodomiro Ignacio
summary: Handwritten sermon preached at the Oratory on the day of S. Philip Neri May 26, 1762, to the city of Seville to celebrate the annual feast devoted to the saint as protector in the aftermath of the Earthquake Sermón en Casa predicado el día de N.P. Sn. Felipe Neri 26 de Mayo de 1762 a la ciudad con motivo de cumplir la fiesta que votó annualmente a N.Sto. como Patrono en la aflicción de terremoto
archive: Seville, Biblioteca del Arzobispado, 61-203, ff. 30r-38r

author: Unknown
summary: Sucinta relación de los trágicos acaecimientos que causó el terremoto en Ciudad de Quito
archive: Barcelona, Biblioteca de Catalunya, Ms. 2531

author: Gertrudis María
recipient: Jesús María y Francisco, María Antonia de
summary: Letter to the Capuchin mother abess of Oaxaca informing her about the Earthquake and the religious responses within the community.
archive: Madrid, Biblioteca de la Real Academia de la Historia, 9/3632(21)

author: Unknown
summary: Account of the Eruption of the pacayita volcano
archive: Seville, Biblioteca Capitular y Colombina, 60-1-02, ff. 331-332

author: Consell de Cent
summary: The great floods of the Llobregat and Besós rivers cause the collapse of the bridges that are there to reach Barcelona, the death of many cattle drowned in the waters and several shipwrecks of boats located near the mouth of these two rivers.
archive: Barcelona, Arxiu Històric de la Ciutat, Dietari de l'Antic Consell Barceloní, 1B. XXV-10

author: Ferdinand of Aragon
summary: Fiscal privilege in the form of a tax suspension granted by the King of Naples to the Università di Pozzuoli. The grace made it clear that the Pozzuoli community's urban buildings and agricultural properties had been damaged by continuous Earthquakes and gaseous exhalations from the Solfatara in previous years. The gracious resolution appealed for distributive justice in favour of the deserving subjects affected by the calamity, which would remedy the expressed intention of the community to leave and abandon the walled city.
archive: Naples, Archivio di Stato di Napoli, Museo, Miscellanea, 99.A, n. 5, ff. 7r-9r

author: Iacobo, Notar
summary: Chronicle of Notar Iacobo reporting an Earthquake felt in Naples on 25 May 1469.
archive: Naples, Biblioteca Nazionale Vittorio Emanuele III, MS Brancacciano II F 6, Notar Iacobo, Cronica di Napoli, paragraph 175

author: Afeltro, Antonio de
summary: Chronicle by Antonio d'Afeltro reporting an Earthquake felt in Naples on 26 May 1468.
archive: Naples, Biblioteca della Società Napoletana di Storia Patria, Manoscritti, XXVIII.B.3, Notamenti cavati dalle scritture di Antonio d’Afeltro

author: Ferraiolo
summary: Ferraiolo's chronicle indicates how an Earthquake in March 1497 caused serious damage to the territory and the episcopate of Pozzuoli.
archive: New York, Pierpont Morgan Library, MS. M 801, paragraph 222

author: Iacobo, Notar
summary: Notar Giacomo's chronicle indicates that an Earthquake in March 1499 (the date is probably 1497) was felt in Naples without causing any damage. Processions were organised in response.
archive: Naples, Biblioteca Nazionale Vittorio Emanuele III, MS Brancacciano II F 6, Notar Iacobo, Cronica di Napoli

author: Lucido Cattaneo, Giovanni (Gonzaga diplomatic agent in Rome)
summary: Diplomatic correspondence testifying to the fear that the great and dangerous Earthquake swarm caused in October 1498 in Pozzuoli and Naples, where it caused damage.
archive: Mantua, Archivio di Stato di Mantova, Archivio Gonzaga, b. 852, ff. 407r, 412 r

author: Casati, Francesco (Sforza's diplomatic agent in Naples)
summary: Diplomatic correspondence testifying to the Earthquake that caused damage in Pozzuoli and was felt in Naples in October 1498.
archive: Milan, Archivio di Stato di Milano, Sforzesco, Carteggio estero, Napoli, b. 1244

author: Consell de Cent
summary: A great storm that fell at dawn causes great flooding throughout the plain of Barcelona, remaining as a large lake. The force of the waters endangers the portals of the north of the city.
archive: Barcelona, Arxiu Històric de la Ciutat, Dietari de l'Antic Consell Barceloní, 1B. XXV-15

author: Unknown
summary: Title: Temblor de tierra. It's a transcription of two reports of the Seville Earthquake of 1504 plus one of the Andalusia Earthquake of 1680
archive: Seville, Biblioteca Capitular y Colombina, 59-1-5

author: Unknown
summary: Title: Terrible y espantoso terremoto, y temblor de tierra en Sevilla y otras muchas partes y alrrededores de su comarca, sacado del testimonio que escrito en latín en pergamino se guarda en la Iglesia mayor traducido fielmente en castellano
archive: Seville, Archivo Capitular, ACS - Sec. IX - Leg. 11291 - Exp. 6

author: Consell de Cent
summary: The Consell de Cent orders the reconstruction of the Sant Boi bridge because the avenue of the Llobregat River has demolished it completely.
archive: Barcelona, Arxiu Històric de la Ciutat, Registre de Deliberacions, 1 B. II-37, f. 77

author: Consell de Cent
summary: There are still 24 pontoons to be built to finish the bridge that demolished the avenues of the Llobregat river in 1505.
archive: Barcelona, Arxiu Històric de la Ciutat, Registre de Deliberacions, 1 B. II-39, f. 15 and 18

author: Iacobo, Notar
summary: Chronicle by Notar Giacomo testifying to the seismic swarm felt in Naples on 25 January 1508.The chronicler Giuliano Passero also provides an almost identical description of the event, but dates it to 19 July 1508: Giuliano Passero, Storie in forma di Giornali, ed. by Vincenzo Maria Altobelli, Naples, Vincenzo Orsino, 1785, p. 154.
archive: Naples, Biblioteca Nazionale Vittorio Emanuele III, MS Brancacciano II F 6, Notar Iacobo, Cronica di Napoli, paragraph 563

author: Atri, Giacomo de (Gonzaga diplomatic agent in Naples)
summary: The Gonzaga's diplomatic agent in Naples reported a strong Earthquake felt in Naples on 25 January, but there was no damage.
archive: Mantua, Archivio di Stato di Mantova, Archivio Gonzaga, b. 808, f. 308

author: Atri, Giacomo de
summary: The Gonzaga's diplomatic agent in Naples reports a strong Earthquake in Pozzuoli that ruined many houses and caused great fear among those who were there for the baths. It is doubtful that the calamity will lead the city to depopulation.
archive: Mantua, Archivio di Stato di Mantova, Archivio Gonzaga, b. 808, f. 322

author: Cardona, Ramón de (Viceroy of Naples)
summary: Privilege granted by Viceroy Ramón de Cardona in 1511. The text of the privilege recognised that Pozzuoli's buildings had been destroyed by recurrent Earthquakes and granted the Università a benefit already experienced in October 1503 by Grand Captain Gonzalo Fernández de Córdoba. Not a tax benefit, but the confirmation of the possibility of building on state land that had emerged as a result of the bradyseism phenomenon.
archive: Naples, Archivio di Stato di Napoli, Museo, Miscellanea, 99.A, n. 5, ff. 14v–16r

author: Consell de Cent
summary: The inhabitants of Barcelona feel a great Earthquake that causes them great fear. Two days later another Earthquake occurs, but of small intensity. No major damage occurs.
archive: Barcelona, Arxiu Històric de la Ciutat, Dietari de l'Antic Consell Barceloní, 1B. XXV-15

author: Antimaco, Federico (Gonzaga diplomatic agent in Naples)
summary: The Gonzaga diplomatic agent reports to the Marchesa about the Earthquake that has struck the city of Naples. The Earthquake has not caused the ruin of houses or buildings, but it is feared that the event is the prelude to future disasters.
archive: Mantua, Archivio di Stato di Mantova, Archivio Gonzaga, b. 809, f. 295r

author: Leo X (Pope)
summary: Papal bull reducing the ecclesiastical tithes that the Chapter of Pozzuoli owed to the Apostolic See in consideration of the meagre income of the Church of Pozzuoli due to the Earthquakes that usually occur.
archive: Pozzuoli, Archivio Storico della Diocesi di Pozzuoli, Sezione II, Capitolo dei Canonici, Pergamene, n. 167

author: Charles V
summary: The content of the privilege begins by portraying the inhabitants of Pozzuoli as faithful vassals who, due to the necessity and poverty caused by continuous Earthquakes, supplicated the sovereign authority to guarantee them the franchises and immunities already granted by previous rulers. The privilege therefore confirmed the various benefits that constituted the state-owned nature of the locality, adding that the proceeds collected from the fair dedicated to one of the city's patron saints, St Proculus, would be used to repair the walls damaged by the Earthquake.
archive: Naples, Archivio di Stato di Napoli, Museo, Miscellanea, 99.A, n. 5, ff. 18r–23r

author: Consell de Cent
summary: Strong Earthquake in the city of Barcelona, with slight aftershocks during the next two days. Only material damage occurs.
archive: Barcelona, Arxiu Històric de la Ciutat, Dietari de l'Antic Consell Barceloní, 1B. XXV-15

author: Villasante, Salazar de
summary: In this geographical report relación geográfica, the author (formerly governor then auditor in Quito) describes the volcanoes around Quito and describes several Eruptions, including the 1534 Cotopaxi Eruption, that occurred at the time of the arrival of the Spaniards in Ecuador
archive: Seville, Archivo General de Indias, Patronato, Leg. 28, 20

author: Consell de Cent
summary: The floods of the Llobregat River have demolished some arches of the bridge. Crossing the river to go or come from Barcelona is very dangerous because of the state of the bridge.
archive: Barcelona, Arxiu Històric de la Ciutat, Registre de Deliberacions, 1B.II-53, f. 51

author: Consell de Cent
summary: The Consell de Cent orders to repair the Dam of Flix because the floods of the Ebro River have caused significants damages.
archive: Barcelona, Arxiu Històric de la Ciutat, Registre de Deliberacions, 1B. II-53, f. 60

author: Valdés, Juan de
summary: Letter from Juan de Valdés writing to Cardinal Ercole Gonzaga from Naples in January 1537 about the viceroy Pedro de Toledo's reluctance to leave Pozzuoli despite the city being subject to the growing risk of barbarian invasions and Earthquakes.
archive: Mantua, Archivio di Stato di Mantova, Archivio Gonzaga, b. 1906, ff. 691r-v

author: Strozzi, Alessandro (Medici diplomatic agent in Rome)
recipient: Medici, Cosimo I de (Duke of Florence)
summary: The Medici agent Alessandro Strozzi reported that on the first day of Lent 1537, around mid-February, great tremors considerably damaged houses and the cathedral of Pozzuoli. The house where the Viceroy was staying was also partly ruined and people were reduced to sleeping in the countryside. In conclusion, the Medici diplomat ruled out the possibility that the inhabitants of Pozzuoli had taken refuge in Naples so far that they had wandered in the area of Capua
archive: Florence, Archivio di Stato di Firenze, Mediceo del Principato, b. 3260, f. 51v

author: Toledo, Pedro de (Viceroy of Naples); Loffredo, Francesco de (Regent of the Consiglio Collaterale)
summary: Response by the Consiglio Collaterale to the Università of Pozzuoli's petition to oppose the new royal captain's action of imprisoning numerous debtors. The Università had obtained the court's approval of an indult so that, as the city had been damaged by the Eruption, it had been necessary to uninhabit and then facilitate the centre's re-inhabitation.
archive: Naples, Archivio di Stato di Napoli, Cancelleria e Consiglio, Collaterale, Cancelleria, Partium, b. 15, ff. 196r-v

author: Toledo, Pedro de (Viceroy of Naples); Loffredo, Francesco de (Regent of the Consiglio Collaterale)
recipient: Regia Camera della Sommaria; Castiglio, Cristoforo del (Tax collector of Terra di Lavoro)
summary: Response by the Consiglio Collaterale to the petition submitted by the Università of Pozzuoli to be exempted from the harassment of the tax collector who wanted to collect the new tax. The measure took into account the state of calamity and necessity invoked by the community, according to which the payment of an extraordinary tax would cause their ruin and force them to leave the city. The Consiglio Collaterale therefore ordered the Regia Camera della Sommaria and the collectors of donations to enforce this exemption.
archive: Naples, Archivio di Stato di Napoli, Cancelleria e Consiglio, Collaterale, Cancelleria, Partium, b. 17, ff. 206r-v

author: Regia Camera della Sommaria; Toledo, Pedro de (Viceroy of Naples)
summary: Resolution of the Regia Camera della Sommaria to exempt the Università of Pozzuoli from paying the tax due as a subsidy to the soldiers. The text recalls the petition in which the community defined itself as being in a state of poverty and need due to the ruin and damage suffered from the Eruption. This was a grace in addition to the previous exemptions without which residents would not have been able to settle in Pozzuoli.
archive: Naples, Archivio di Stato di Napoli, Regia Camera Sommaria, Segreteria, Partium, reg. 238, ff. 174v-175v

author: Pacca, Cola Anello
summary: Chronicle of the Monte Nuovo Eruption.
archive: Naples, Biblioteca della Società Napoletana di Storia Patria, SISMICA, MANOSCRITTI, 7/A3, Colanello Pacca, Discorso del terremoto, 1563-1580, cc. DXXXVI-DXXXVIIII

author: Castaldo, Antonino
summary: Notary Antonino Castaldo vividly recounted the impact of the Eruption on the people of Naples, describing it as a horrible and miserable spectacle. He cites a fervent sermon by the theologian Fra Angelo of Naples, who interpreted the Eruption as a divine warning against human viciousness. The preacher's message aligned with the increase in devotional processions in Naples after the disaster.
archive: Naples, Biblioteca Nazionale Vittorio Emanuele III, MS. XB48, Antonino Castaldo, Diario delle cose occorse in Napoli, ff. 61v-65r

author: Del Nero, Francesco
summary: Copy of the contents of the letter that Francesco Del Nero, a witness to the 1538 Eruption, wrote to Niccolò del Benino, giving a vivid account of the impact of the disaster. Del Nero, a Florentine businessman and relative of Machiavelli, described the transformation of the once enchanting Pozzuoli into a fiery nightmare. He also expressed his inability to comprehend the immense volume of incandescent materials ejected from the crater in just two days.Del Nero mentioned the scholarly discussions surrounding the event, acknowledging the writings of Simone Porzio and the viceroy Pedro de Toledo's response, which involved digging numerous deep pits to extinguish the fire. Del Nero's letter reflects the popular perception of the Eruption during his time.Del Nero compared the Eruption to a pyrotechnic display at Castel Sant'Angelo, like the one held to celebrate the marriage between Margaret, daughter of Emperor Charles V, and Ottavio Farnese in November 1538, the month after the date of the letter.
archive: Mantua, Archivio di Stato di Mantova, Archivio Gonzaga, 830, rubr. E.XXIV.5., cc. 635r-637v

author: Consiglio Collaterale
summary: Response of the Consiglio Collaterale to the petition formulated by the Università of Pozzuoli. In the petition, reported in the reply, the community represented itself as almost uninhabited and in ruins due to the Earthquakes that struck the Phlegraean area in 1536-1538. The expenses that the city administration had to face in order to materially manage the emergency made it impossible to liquidate the donative established by the Viceroy and the Consiglio Collaterale in the preceding months and for which the Università requested a gracious exemption.
archive: Naples, Archivio di Stato di Napoli, Cancelleria e Consiglio, Collaterale, Cancelleria, Curiae, busta 9, f. 147r

author: Castaldo, Antonino (Notary)
summary: In his chronicle, the Neapolitan notary Antonino Castaldo describes a Pozzuoli that on Holy Saturday 1538 (20 April) was damaged in its urban buildings by an Earthquake. The notary's narrative, which also describes how people took refuge to sleep in the fields, focuses on the reaction of collective fear triggered by the telluric violence.
archive: Naples, Biblioteca Nazionale Vittorio Emanuele III, MS. XB48, Antonino Castaldo, Diario delle cose occorse in Napoli, ff. 61r-v

author: Consell de Cent

author: Cobo, Bernabé
summary: The disaster is told by the jesuit on pages 96-101 (vol. 1, f from Francisco Mateos' edition). Cobo, who was in Lima at the time of the Eruption, describes in detail some of the phenomena that occurred during the disaster in and around the city of Arequipa. In particular, his initial explanation of the geology of the place, specifying the volcanoes present in the area; the details of the evolution of the sound and visual sensations that accompanied the phenomenon (noises, lack of light, colour of the sky, etc.); the human damages (destruction of indigenous villages) and material damages caused to houses and crops, which amounted to 10 million pesos; the effects on the landscape and environment (change in the course of the Tambo river, crumbling of hills, death of livestock and fish, etc.); the reactions of the indigenous and Spanish populations: the former tended to return to their idolatrous practices, eating meat during Lent, drinking to the point of drunkenness and hanging themselves to avoid a painful death; the latter sticking to Christian practices of communion and penance, processions and prayers.

author: Unknown (He was a Jesuit)
summary: The letter is from a Jesuit from the school in Arequipa who gives a day-by-day account of the Eruption of the Omate volcano (Huaynaputina): from Friday 18 February to Saturday 26 February. For each of the days, the author refers to the ash rain, the thunderstorm with lightning and thunder, the Earthquakes and the darkness both day and night experienced by the inhabitants of Arequipa. He also dwells on the processions and sermons given by the Society of Jesus, the Augustinians and the Dominicans, and on the behaviour and emotions of the population (confessions, penitence, terror, sadness, etc.). Only at the end of the letter, which must have been written on different days, does the author mention that news has arrived that it might be about a volcano near the town of Omate. The anonymous Jesuit also focuses on the material damage caused by the Eruption and its effects on other localities more or less distant from Arequipa.
archive: Rome, Archivum Romanum Societatis Jesu, Peru 19, ff. 70 et seq.

author: Lira, Gonzalo de
summary: Gonzalo de Lira highlights the assistance of the Society of Jesus to the poor, prisoners and Indians affected by famine after the Eruption of Huaynaputina in February 1600. He asked the bishop of Cuzco, Antonio de Raya, for help in supplying food.
archive: Rome, Archivum Romanum Societatis Jesu, Peru 19, ff. 96r-97v

author: Mexía Fernangil, Diego

author: Cabredo, Rodrigo de
summary: Cabredo, in his annual letter to the General, recounts the events of the last year in the college of Arequipa and dwells on the effects of the Eruption on the population. Among them, the help given by the Jesuits to the population, the penitences and processions organised, and the consequences on agriculture and geography. He describes the natural causes of the Eruption, as well as its empirical effects (types of thunder, mudslides, landslides, etc.). Special attention is given to the indigenous peoples and their sorcerers, in particular to the way in which those who continued to practise their cults reacted. He also refers to how their diabolical divinities would have decided to punish those Indians who had abandoned their religion to embrace Christian
archive: Rome, Archivum Romanum Societatis Jesu, Perú 12, ff. 188-226v

author: Cabredo, Rodrigo de
summary: Cabredo informs the General that the harmful effects of the Eruption continue on the crops of Arequipa. He assures him that the preaching of the Jesuits has attributed the cause of the disaster to God's punishment and that its cessation will only come with the collaboration between secular and ecclesiastical justice in the denunciation of sinners and the exiling of the scandalous. But the hand of the devil would have prevented this collaboration from taking place. The devil himself was the cause of the destruction of the Indians who a few days before the Eruption were going to mass to obey the call of their priest. Cabredo also refers to the commemorations held on the day of the disaster (fasting and blood procession) as well as the declaration of San Gennaro as patron saint of the city. The Jesuit prefect was building a church to this saint that the bishop of Cuzco had decided to transform into a parish. Finally, Cabredo claims that the ashes from the Eruption have reached Nueva España, where they have destroyed the cocoa crop, and Tucumán, where they are said to have affected the cotton crop.
archive: Rome, Archivum Romanum Societatis Jesu, Perù 12, ff. 228-259v

author: Unknown
summary: The manuscript containing the account of the college of Arequipa for the year 1600 is the second part of an anonymous History of the Society of Jesus in Peru. The description of the college of Arequipa for 1600 narrates the Eruption of Huaynaputina in February of that year and describes, with slight variations, many of the events referred to in Rodrigo de Cabredo's letter of 30 April 1601 (present in this database).
archive: Rome, Archivum Romanum Societatis Jesu, Perù 26

author: Montesinos, Fernando
summary: Montesinos claims that the 1600 Eruption of the volcano called 'Cerro del Volcán' devastated the city of Arequipa and that the ash rain it caused lasted more than 40 days. The ash reached as far as Acapulco, New Spain. He points out that a Franciscan baptised the volcano, which he managed to reach after a climb that lasted five days. Thanks to the religious man, says Montesinos, no noise can be heard from the volcano today.
archive: Madrid, Biblioteca Nacional de España, MSS/3124; MSS.MICRO/11198

author: Cacho de Santillana, Cristóbal
summary: Cacho de Santillana informs the king of the Earthquake, since the viceroy had decided to grant aid to the wretched of Trujillo. He specifies the damage suffered by the population (300 people died) and by the houses of the Spaniards and Indians. Those of the Indians were less affected because they were lighter. He affirms that the Earthquake was felt in Lima and that when it happened, from Trujillo the cabildo, the bishop and the corregidor Luis de Esquivel wrote to the authorities in Lima to give notice. News arrived on the 22nd. He praises the action of the said corregidor and requests a mercy for him. Likewise, Cacho de Santillana affirms that Trujillo requested to change the location of the city and Indians to facilitate its reconstruction. After a meeting of the Audiencia, Cacho de Santillana states that he met with the viceroy to tell him that in a similar event, Arequipa had been helped by granting it Indians and tax exemptions. The viceroy decided to grant Trujillo 10,000 ducats of which 4,000 were to be given as alms to the nuns. He refers to the letter he had already sent to the king in 1610 on the occasion of an Earthquake in Lima in which he warned of the need to remedy the Earthquakes by constructing low buildings and opening wells. But he assures us that the viceroys forget these suggestions when the danger has passed. He ends by referring to some prodigies that preceded the Earthquake.
archive: Seville, Archivo General de Indias, LIMA, 96

author: Rodríguez Ocampo, Diego
summary: In his description of the Chille Valley, the author recalls the Eruption of the Antisana volcano three decades earlier, mentioning its effects on the surrounding area, some of which are still visible. He also recalls that the Franciscan friar had predicted that Eruption and the destruction of that area. Finally, he argues that thanks to that Eruption the ordinary Earthquakes were calmed, also through the intercession of Saint Jerome
archive: Madrid, Biblioteca de la Real Academia de la Historia, A/93, Col. Muñoz T. 66, Descripción y relación del estado eclesiastico del Obispado de S. Francisco de Quito

author: Padavino, Marcantonio (Venetian Resident in Naples)

archive: Venice, Archivio di Stato di Venezia, Senato, Dispacci, Dispacci degli ambasciatori e residenti, Napoli, filze, 51, n. 143

author: Padavino, Marcantonio (Venetian Resident in Naples)
summary: Dispatch from the Venetian Resident on the damage caused by the Eruption, including the annual supply of wine produced in Ottaviano on which his family relied and which consequently increased in price. All trade stopped in the city, while only devotional processions continued. Orders were given to open the streets and assist the fugitives.
archive: Venice, Archivio di Stato di Venezia, Senato, Dispacci, Dispacci degli ambasciatori e residenti, Napoli, filze, 51, n. 145

author: Tarfaglione, Severo (Carthusian of the Certosa di San Martino)
summary: The manuscript text by the Carthusian friar Dom Severo Tarfaglione traces the history of the previous Eruptions. Then, the author records day by day the course of events and life in Naples during these days. Tarfaglione finally presents the Eruption as an emanation from the hell.
archive: Carpentras, Bibliothèque Inguimbertine, . ms 1821, ff. 178r-194r

author: Padavino, Marcantonio (Venetian Resident in Naples)
summary: The Venetian Resident reports that the change in the wind brought ash from the still erupting Vesuvius to the city, causing fear in the city. The loss of the mills and the shortage of flour forced the city to supply food from Benevento and places further afield. However, the population is still reluctant to return to their trade. The river of lava flowing in the direction of Nola damaged numerous houses and claimed several victims. The death toll, according to information gathered by the Venetian representative, reaches six to seven thousand people, while the loss of livestock due to the ash-covered pastures is incalculable.
archive: Venice, Archivio di Stato di Venezia, Senato, Dispacci, Dispacci degli ambasciatori e residenti, Napoli, filze, 51, n. 149

author: Padavino, Marcantonio (Venetian Resident in Naples)
summary: The Venetian Resident reports that the response of the Neapolitan government was too weak to cope with the emergency of the Eruption. The lack of grain could drive many people away from the city, but at the same time there is a significant insurrectionary tension.
archive: Venice, Archivio di Stato di Venezia, Senato, Dispacci, Dispacci degli ambasciatori e residenti, Napoli, filze, 51, n. 151

author: Padavino, Marcantonio (Venetian Resident in Naples)
summary: The Venetian Resident reports that the Viceroy, having returned from Pozzuoli, is the object, together with the entire government, of an attack in the form of a pasquinade. The attack, entitled 'Relatione dell'incendio del monte di Somma', blames the Viceroy for the destruction caused by the Eruption.
archive: Venice, Archivio di Stato di Venezia, Senato, Dispacci, Dispacci degli ambasciatori e residenti, Napoli, filze, 51, n. 156
